content: Let me know if I missed questions, if you have other questions or if something is still unclear. Also, please reach out again if the situation doesn't improve. ðŸ™‚

Regarding node count. If you scale up, you should always start from 3 nodes. That is so there's always a 'majority' if one node dies. A 'majority' is required for the cluster to properly recover.
2 nodes would be 1/1, 3 nodes would be 2/1.
Scaling to multiple nodes _could_ make performance better, but it is not a magical solution. I recommend to try improving performance on a single node first like we've just discussed.

Here's some context as to what our service as a whole does. We connect with our customers' users' external data sources (e.g. files, notion, websites, google drive, etc), parse their data, generate embeddings for them, and store those embeddings in qdrant. We resync any updated data (in parts, not all at once) in 10-20 minute intervals as well. This involves upserting vectors related to the updated data. Once data has been synced into our system, our customers' users can then query it when they want.

Some apps our customers use us for are chatbots, search engines (e.g. over scientific papers), etc.

content:
I hope that explains this somewhat ðŸ™‚
Feel free to ask further questions on this!
I think the bottom line is that: these numbers can be confusing, don't depend on them too much.

In reality, these counters reflect the number of points and/or vectors that are still somewhere in the collection. These include vectors that have already been deleted (and no, these would never be returned with regular searches).
Our optimization process that run in the background eventually clean these up. Then the counters should show a more realistic number.
If you update existing points, this gets even more complicated.

To give a very basic example:

If you would delete a point:
- it would delete the point
- decrease point counter by one

However, this does not:
- delete the associated vector
- decrease vector counter by one

This would be one of the reasons why these counters may appear a bit weird.

We did do this propagation before, but it turned out to be problematic. Don't worry though, this doesn't mean that vectors stay forever.
The problem is that when you delete or update existing points, these counters start to diverge.
It is true that you can have multiple vectors for a point. So generally, if you'd have 2 named vectors in a collection, your vector count would be twice as much.

yes, this is also an option. However, points are variable. I would go with the mapping collection. Let's see how it performs.

If you always have the same number of points, then another approach would be to use ID 1..max. Then every time you update points you use this same sequence. That way you now what IDs are used  and constantly overwrite them with every new update.
I do not recommend this though, as this can be very error prone.

If you constantly want to replace your full collection, you may also use this approach:
- create a new collection
- insert all new data
- alias the new collection to a common name, such as `my_collection`

Then, when you update again, you:
- create a new collection
- insert all new data
- update the alias from the old collection to the new collection, so that `my_collection` now access the new collection
- remove the old collection

For all following updates you simply repeat this.

You can find more on aliases here: https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/collections/#collection-aliases

Hi!

So, the way Qdrant works (in a cluster deployment) it does not provide the same strict consistency guarantees like, e.g., CockroachDB (which is distributed SQL DB with strict consistency guarantess) does. In some (generally rare) cases it is possible for node to, e.g., miss an update, and you might end up with nodes with slightly divergent data.

_By default_, when you do a search for a point, a node will execute a combination of local and network (to other node(s) in the cluster) requests and (simplifying a little bit) return the first result (from whatever node that replied first). So, if you hit that corner case, where data is diverged, if you repeat the same request multiple times (even on the same node), you might receive slightly different response each time.

`read_consistency` allows user to selectively override this behavior, if they want stronger consistency guarantees.

In particular, `read_consistency = 2` would make a node to execute 2 (local and network) requests and then only return points that present in both responses. (`majority` and `all` works the same way.)

`read_consistency = "quorum"` sends requests to _all_ nodes in the cluster, and returns points that present at the majority (e.g., half of all nodes + 1) nodes.

Hope this makes it clear.
https://qdrant.to/cloud

Our node which was hosting a single instance qdrant cluster was restarted as part of routine management from GCP. This resulted in qdrant entering an endless silent crashloop cycle. The logs got as far as "rebuilding collection" then the process would exit without any obvious message as to what or why caused it to panic.

I tried increasing the size of the node to have 128GB RAM - but this didn't work. I increased the log level to DEBUG, but no additional helpful logs were reported. I increased the timings for the readiness / liveness probes in case it was external termination from kubernetes - agian this didn't help.

Config settings are as per the defaults in the helm chart deployment. Unfortunately I really needed the service running again, and so the only way I found to get it to successfully launch was by deleting the persistent volume (and thus the backing data for the collections). This the allowed the service to start without any issues. I think at the time of failure we had around 10,000 - 15,000 vectors of length 768, including some metadata.

I guess the main request of this, is what else should I be trying to do if this happens again to understand what is going wrong, and hopefully recover without dropping the whole database, requiring a lengthy rebuild of the system.
